Macro
Tooltip: Risks, which arise from factors at the national or global levels.

Title: Political and legal
Tooltip: In this section, we consider risks arising from factors such as government policies, regulations, and laws. The section is particularly important in highly regulated industries.

Title: Economic
Tooltip: Here we consider factors that depend on the overall functioning of the economy. These may include fluctuations in interest rates and foreign exchange rates (particularly in exporting industries and industries relying on imports), changes in the overall wealth and income in the economy, business cycles (booms and recessions), inflation, quality of infrastructure (e.g., roads and airports), access to financial markets/ credit, and availability of human resources.

Title: Social
Tooltip: This category focuses on shifts in tastes, lifestyle trends, and cultural norms and values. Changes in the demographic composition of the population also fall in this category.

Title: Technological
Tooltip: This category focuses on all risks pertaining to technology. Most importantly, this includes technological developments that can render companies in the industry in question obsolete. (As an example, consider the advent of personal computers, which caused the demise of typewriters.) In addition, this category also includes risks that arise from the use of technology, particularly, information and communications technology, cybersecurity being the prime example.

Title: Environmental
Tooltip: This category includes risks pertaining to ecology and the environment. Two main subcategories are prominent: climate change and natural disasters.

Title: Industry
Tooltip: Risks, which result from the industry-specific market structure

Title: Existing competition
Tooltip: Here we talk about the market structure of the industry in question, focusing on how easy or hard it would be for a new entrant to survive (and be profitable) in this market. The risk is evaluated from the perspective of the entrant (our new entrepreneur).

Title: Potential competition
Tooltip: This category discusses the threat of new entry. It is therefore the flipside of the previous category. Here we talk about the extent to which our enterprise, once it establishes itself in the market, will be threatened by future entrants (i.e., unlike the previous category, here our entrepreneur is in the shoes of an existing player, not an entrant).

Title: Substitution possibilities
Tooltip: This category concerns the extent to which the emergence of new substitute products/ services might displace those of companies in the industry in question.

Title: Power of suppliers
Tooltip: This category evaluates the market power of the suppliers of inputs to the industry in question.

Title: Power of buyers
Tooltip: This category evaluates the market power of the buyers of the outputs (products or services) of the industry in question.

Title: Company
Tooltip: Risks, which originate internally within the company.

Title: Resources: Human
Tooltip: Under this category, we discuss company-level risks pertaining to human resources.

Title: Resources: Tangible
Tooltip: Under this category, we discuss company-level risks pertaining to tangible resources (physical capital), such as equipment and buildings.

Title: Processes
Tooltip: Under this category, we discuss company-level risks pertaining to production, distribution, and management processes.
